Dozens of businesspeople in dark suits gathered at a San Diego hotel this week, sipping wine and snacking on hors d'oeuvres before a panel discussion on what was billed as the hottest topic in corporate governance: CEO pay.
Analyst Carol Miltner chairs the compensation committees of two public companies in California.
She calls the double-digit jumps in CEOs' pay a big red flag.
The board isn't doing their job.
They should find a CEO who understands his job is to create wealth for the shareholder, not for himself alone.
Much of the panel discussion focused on possible changes in the way public companies report executive pay.
Next week, the Securities and Exchange Commission will consider its first update to reporting rules in 14 years.

Commission Chairman Christopher Cox says the government does not intend to limit compensation, but it does want to give investors a better idea of what executives make, including salary, stock options and corporate perks.
Investors' shock and surprise over some pay packages have put the boards of directors that approved them on the defensive.
Miltner believes that in itself may limit big pay hikes in the future.
